ETYMOLOGY: From Late Latin 'categoria', from Greek 'katēgoria' (accusation, predicate, class), from 'katēgorein' (accuse, assert).

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A class or division of people or things regarded as having particular shared characteristics.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 具有特定共同特征的人或事物的分类或类别。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The books are arranged into different categories based on their subject matter.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 这些书根据主题内容被分成了不同的类别。

MEANINGS.POS_TIP: A word (other than a pronoun) used to identify any of a class of people, places, or things, or to name a particular one of these.
MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (In philosophy) A concept or fundamental type of predication; a fundamental and irreducible concept used in logical or metaphysical analysis.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: （哲学）一种概念或基本的谓词类型；用于逻辑或形而上学分析的基本且不可还原的概念。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: Aristotle's categories include substance, quantity, quality, and relation.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 亚里士多德的范畴包括实体、数量、性质和关系。
